awd_titl_txt: Workshop on innovation in hot water system design to meet simultaneous water quality, public health, and conservation objectives
awd_abstract_narration:
Hot water systems include water heaters, pipes, and connected fixtures to supply hot water within buildings. These systems require  a complex interplay of performance requirements and risk trade-offs, while supplying hot water of appropriate temperature, pressure, chemical, and microbiological water quality to protect human health. Improper operation of hot water systems can lead to the growth of plumbing pathogens like Legionella pneumophila, production of disinfection byproducts and other toxic compounds, inefficient energy consumption, and water wastage. Proper management of hot water systems thus requires a cross disciplinary approach to avoid such adverse outcomes. This grant will support costs for a hybrid workshop consisting of virtual meetings and a two-day in-person workshop focused on innovations in hot water system design. The goal of the workshop is to develop a common level of knowledge across disciplines related to water quality, public health, building science, and energy. The in-person workshop will advance interdisciplinary hot water system convergence research focused on water quality, energy efficiency, and protection of human health through the control of Legionella and other pathogens. Expected outputs are a project report, peer reviewed manuscripts, and facilitation of interdisciplinary research collaborations for potential future research.
 
This grant will support costs for a blended virtual/in-person workshop focused on innovation in hot water system design to meet simultaneous water quality, public health, and conservation objectives. The overall goal of the workshop is to identify the science to assess the hypothesis that hot water systems can be reengineered as beneficial and distributed treatment applications that significantly control and improve downpipe chemical and microbial water quality while still maintaining thermal efficiency through their design life. The specific goals of this workshop designed to achieve this goal include a focus on i) facilitating interdisciplinary knowledge exchange related to the fundamental processes involved in hot water systems and their impact on residential public health; ii) reimagining hot water systems as a series of treatments and practices that reduce the contaminants rather a system that exerts a contamination surcharge; and iii) catalyzing networking between groups of interdisciplinary researchers for future research collaborations related to hot water system improvements and innovation. Dissemination of results from this project will be achieved through a project report, peer reviewed manuscripts, and compilation of a bibliography of area-specific and hot water system specific literature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This workshop was focused on a narrow subject--hot water systems--yet a vital subject with wide-ranging impacts on industry and civil society. Over the course of the grant period we organized and hosted three webinars and panel discussions, open to the public, in which subject matter experts presented their perspectives on hot water systems.  Each webinar focused on one aspect of hot water systems from biological growth and pathogen control to exploring the water-energy nexus and concerns for the indoor environment.  Webinars were organized as a series of six, 5 min expert panelist presentations and an extensive 30-40 min discussion and Q&A. The webinars were well attended and produced lively discussions that cut across subject matter boundaries that advanced consideration of hot water systems within the audience as well as among panelists. Webinars were recorded and posted for viewing and formed the basis for a publication currently submitted for review.

For the expert panelist participants, we then ran a two-day hybrid workshop where we explored the interconnectivity of our disciplines within hot water systems and identified knowledge gaps and innovation opportunities. The hybrid workshop began with an effort to develop consensus on what comprises a hot water system. Pivotal realizations made as hot water systems were defined were the importance of the user as components of the hot water system and that hot water distribution is at least as important as water heating in determining water quality, water use, and energy use. The workshops culminated in a set of research pitches by collaborative teams. Research pitches were developed to fill critical knowledge gaps identified over the course of the workshop and such that the research would enable hot water system innovation.  Research pitches are being developed into full research projects and proposals by interdisciplinary teams drawn from the diverse participants and institutions at the workshop.  The connections made at the workshop led to us initiating and hosting a forum regarding ongoing academic research at a NIST Co-Organized Hot Water Systems conference, and the initiation of a Building Water Performance goals working group to author guidelines on performance goals.  These connections are notable both as continuations of the workshop and because they are breaking down siloes that have traditionally limited hot water system research and innovation, particularly the divide between researchers and practitioners focused with thermal and mechanical aspects of hot water systems and those focused on water quality. The initiation of the Building Performance Goals working group is particularly timely since jurisdictions are increasingly developing building performance standards, but often without a wholistic outlook that includes water conservation and water quality management.

The efforts of the group resulted in one manuscript submitted for peer review, a second manuscript in progress, and a white paper in preparation.
